items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: This flood alert has been issued due to strong winds and spring tides which may cause large waves and spray overtopping on the coast tomorrow morning. Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming tides. The area of concern is expected to be at Sandsend between 10:00am and 1:30pm on 17/11/2022. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts or warnings. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 11:00am, 17/11/2022, or earlier as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water

items.message: Thursday's tide from 12:00am to 2:30am and 12:00pm to 3:30pm on 17/11/2022 is higher than normal due to winds and large waves. Areas most at risk include the lifeboat station, north pier and south pier at Bridlington. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 11:00am on 17/11/2022, or earlier as the situation changes.

Persistent heavy rainfall is expected this evening, 16/11/2022, through to tomorrow afternoon, 17/11/2022.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible to begin between 22:00 tonight and 12:00 tomorrow afternoon, 17/11/2022.  
Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land, footpaths and roads.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated 07:00 tomorrow morning, 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the situation and re-issue this alert if necessary. The forecast is for a largely dry night tonight (15/11/22) and tomorrow daytime, with a chance of further rainfall tomorrow evening.

Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

River levels are forecast have risen and are forecast to rise further at the Broadwey river level gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to forecast rainfall this afternoon (16/11/22) . Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Wey, Preston Brook and River Jordan. Consequently flooding of roads and farmland is possible. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 17:00 on Thursday 17th November or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the River Wey as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue this morning, 16/11/22. Further showers are forecast today with more persistent heavy rain this evening. We expect river levels to remain high as a result. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 16/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels are forecast at the Stourbridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall forecast overnight and tomorrow, 17/11/22. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible tomorrow, Thursday 17/11/22. Further showers are forecasted over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high tomorrow, 17/11/22. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Thursday 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible overnight into Thursday 17/11/22.  Flooding could affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.   We are issuing this flood alert as a precautionary measure.
 We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff have cleared weed screens and checked defences ahead of this forecast rain.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/11/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message: River levels are rising at Bradford on Avon and will continue to rise overnight Wednesday and through Thursday morning in response to the forecast rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford and the flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.  Rivers are expected to peak around lunch time on Thursday 17th November.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have been clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated on the morning of Thursday 17th November, or sooner if the situation changes.

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue this morning, 16/11/22, around the Free Prae Road area. Further showers are forecast today with more persistent heavy rain this evening. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 16/11/22, or as the situation changes.

Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible tomorrow, 17/11/22. Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle. Further showers are forecasted over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high tomorrow 17/11/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses. River levels have risen at the Willington Cableway river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this evening, 16/11/22 and for the next few days.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane.   
We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Gilling Beck, Skeeby Beck

items.message: The flood alert for the Upper River Swale has been issued as river levels are forecast to rise in the early hours of Thursday morning 17/11/2022, due to heavy rainfall on Wednesday night 16/11/2022.  Flooding is forecast to affect low lying roads and footpaths near Arkle Beck, around Reeth, from the early hours of Thursday morning onwards. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, avoid low lying footpaths, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Further rainfall is forecast during the day on Thursday which will keep river levels high. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on Thursday 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

The Flood Alert for the River Rye catchment has been issued. River levels are forecast to rise on the river Rye catchment due to rainfall expected in the early hours of Thursday 17/11/2022. Areas most at risk include land around the river Rye and its tributaries, including Ralsdale Beck, River Seph, Ledge Beck, Fangdale Beck, Prodale Beck, Ladhill Beck, Etton Gill, Borough Beck and Spittle Beck, including properties at Salton, Nunnington and Helmsley. In these areas, flooding of land and roads is possible from 6:00 AM on Thursday 17/11/2022.  River levels could remain high throughout Thursday. Further rainfall over the coming days will mean river levels are likely to fluctuate. 
We will continue to monitor levels closely. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 17/11/2022, or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Sharnford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.    Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Sharnford, Croft, Littlethorpe, the Mill on the Soar car park and Falconry.   
Persistent rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Friday afternoon, 18/11/22.

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Mersey due to rainfall on Thursday 17/11/2022.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Mersey, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying land and roads around Micker, Cringle, Sinderland and Poynton Brooks and their tributaries from 9AM on 17/11/2022.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the day tomorrow (17/11/2022) and as a result river levels are forecast to rise.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

Please call 999 if in immediate danger.

items.message: Water levels have risen at the Sherborne Lake river and Chetnole gauge as a result of the recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, there is a low risk of flooding to low-lying land and roads today, Wednesday 16/11/22. Locations most vulnerable to flooding are the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. Further showers are forecast throughout this evening, 16/11/22, and through the early hours, 17/11/22. We expect river levels to remain high over the next 24 hours. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. Please refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Thursday, 17/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Lim, River Char, River Winniford, Simene River, River Brit, River Asker, River Mangerton, River Bride due to rainfall.
Areas most at risk include the Rivers Lim, Char, Winniford, Simene, Brit, Asker, Mangerton and Bride.
Flooding is possible at the Rivers Lim, Char, Winniford, Simene, Brit, Asker, Mangerton and Bride from 03:00 PM on 16/11/2022.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the afternoon.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Hillfarrance Brook, Halsewater Stream, River Tone

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise overnight on the River Tone, Hillfarrance Brook, Halsewater Stream due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is possible at roads around Hillfarrance, Bradford on Tone, Lane End Road at Ham and the Creech St Michael to Henlade road.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

The River Uck is high and rising. Over the last day, 20mm of rain has been recorded at Buxted. Flooding could affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach riverside properties through Buxted, near the White Hart pub and areas around Hempstead Mill on Hempstead Lane, Uckfield. Areas in Uckfield most at risk include The Roller Mill, Mill Lane, River Way, Bridge Cottage & Bell Walk. A further 20-30mm of rain is expected from Wednesday afternoon into the early hours of Thursday morning. The river level should begin to fall by Thursday morning as no further significant rain is forecast. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast and may close our flood gate in the supermarket car park in Uckfield town centre to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 10:00 17/11/22.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message: River levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday and overnight. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue throughout today, 16/11/2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads around Forest Row, Ashurst, Hartfield, Penshurst and particularly on and around Balls Green and Ashurst. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further rainfall is forecast over the next two days. We expect river levels to remain high until Thursday, 17/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated this evening, 16/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.message: River levels have risen as a result of heavy and persistent rainfall overnight and during the morning of Wednesday. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected today, 16/11/2022 and through until Thursday and Friday. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, and we expect river levels to remain high throughout today and throughout Thursday 17/11/2022. River levels are expected to rise again, and we are prepared to issue Flood Warnings if required. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing trash screens across the catchment. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels remained high throughout Tuesday night, 15/11/22, at the Trowbridge Paxcroft river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Levels began to fall in the early hours of Wednesday, 16/11/22, but were then topped up by showery rain. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding may affect the Westbury Road (A363) at Yarnbrook, Hawkeridge Road at Horse Bridge, Shallow Wagon Lane at Heywood and West Ashton Road at Trowbridge. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further rainfall, heavy at times, is forecast for Wednesday afternoon and evening. River levels are forecast to rise again. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated on Wednesday afternoon, 16/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Teise area from Lamberhurst to Goudhurst
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected from 9pm on Wednesday 16 November and will continue overnight. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Teise particularly in Lamberhurst. Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 8 hours until 1am on Thursday 17 November. We expect river levels to remain high overnight.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.  
Please avoid walking or driving through floodwater and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated by 10am on Thursday 17 November, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur is high and rising. Over the last day 30mm of rain has been recorded at Cowfold. Flooding could affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding could also affect gardens of properties near Mock Bridge and may begin to approach buildings too. A further 20-30mm of rain is expected from Wednesday afternoon (16/11/2022) into the early hours of Thursday morning. The river level should begin to fall by Thursday morning as no further significant rain is forecast. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 10:00 17/11/22.

Water levels in the Eastern Yar are currently stable but very high. In the last 48 hours, half a months rain (45mm) was recorded at Wroxall. At Alverstone, the river will be close to the top of the river bank. At Sandown, Golf Links Road and Moreton Common Road will continue to flood, and levels will be high at Sandown Bridge, the sewage treatment plant and Fort Holiday Park. Further heavy rain is forecast over the next 12 hours, with a possible 20mm to 40mm expected. Water levels will begin to rise again and there is a possibility a Flood Warning will be issued later on Wednesday or early Thursday morning (17/11/2022). We are operating the sluice at Bembridge to help reduce water levels across Brading Marshes while neap tides continue over the next few days. We continue to monitor the forecast and will ensure the river remains free of any reported blockages. If you live near the river, please take action now to ensure you can protect your property. This Flood Alert will be updated by 10:00 on Thursday 17/11/20222 or sooner if required.

items.description: River Bourne from Hadlow to East Peckham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are rising rapidly as a result of heavy rainfall overnight and this morning.  Flooding of low-lying land is expected from 1:30pm today, 16/11/22. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Bourne at Hadlow and Little Mill. Further heavy rainfall is forecast this evening through until 6am tomorrow. River levels are expected to rise again overnight in response to this further heavy rainfall. We expect river levels to remain high until Thursday afternoon, 17/11/22.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking our defences and structures.  Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  

This message will be updated by 10pm this evening, Wednesday 16 November or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the River Blackwater and The Cove Brook as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected today 16/11/22. 
The weather forecast is for some further rain showers today, with more persistent heavy rain this evening. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings. 
This message will be updated this evening, 16/11/22, or as the situation changes.

The River Ouse is high and rising. Over the last day, 30mm of rain has been recorded at Ardingly. Flooding could affect fields, rural roads and gardens. Flood water could approach properties at Slaugham Place near Old Hall on Brantridge Lane, Bridge Cottage at Sheffield Park, Dean's Water Mill at Lindfield Bridge on the B2028 near Lindfield, Freshfield Mill Farm, Freshmill and Millers Cottages on Sloop Lane. Roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge will be affected. A further 20-30mm of rain is expected from Wednesday afternoon (16/11/2022) into the early hours of Thursday morning. The river level should begin to fall by Thursday morning as no further significant rain is forecast. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 10:00 17/11/2022.

items.description: River Teise and Lesser Teise area from Horsmonden to Yalding
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have risen as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected from 8pm on Wednesday 16 November and will continue overnight. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Teise and Lesser Teise. Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 8 hours until 1am on Thursday 17 November. We expect river levels to remain high overnight.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.  
Please avoid walking or driving through floodwater and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  
This message will be updated by 10am on Thursday 17 November, or as the situation changes.

The Cuckmere River is high and rising. Over the last day, 20mm of rain has been recorded at Cowbeech. Flooding could affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach properties on Mill Lane, Hellingly, Grove Hill near Grovebridge Farm and Hammer Lane near Cowbeech. From Wednesday evening flood impacts could also affect Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly, and gardens of properties on those roads. Flooding could also affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. A further 20-30mm of rain is expected from Wednesday afternoon into the early hours of Thursday morning. The river level should begin to fall by Thursday morning as no further significant rain is forecast. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 10:00 17/11/22.

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected between 11pm tonight on Wednesday 16 November and to continue into Thursday, between Stonegate and Robertsbridge.  
Further heavy rainfall is forecast overnight. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Thursday 17 November. 

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Avoid walking or driving through floodwater and please stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  

This message will be updated by 10am on Thursday 17 November or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels have risen as a result of heavy and persistent rainfall overnight and during the morning of Wednesday. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected today, 16/11/2022 and through until Thursday and Friday. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, and we expect river levels to remain high throughout today and throughout Thursday 17/11/2022. River levels are expected to rise again, and we are prepared to issue Flood Warnings if required. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing trash screens across the catchment. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury on the River Adur
items.message: The River Adur is high and rising. Over the last day and a half, 30mm of rain has been recorded at Cowfold. From 16:00 Wednesday (16/11/2022) flooding will affect the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. As well as extensive water in fields, flooding will also affect properties near Mock Bridge and their gardens. A further 20-30mm of rain is expected from Wednesday afternoon into the early hours of Thursday morning. The river should begin to fall by late Thursday (17/11/2022), and should return to normal from Friday (18/11/2022). Flood impacts should begin to slowly ease when river levels start to fall. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 17/11/2022.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of low-lying land and towpaths is expected from 5pm today, Wednesday 16 November. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and towpaths along the River Medway between Wateringbury and Maidstone Town Centre, particularly in the Lockmeadow area.   

Further heavy rain is forecast later this evening on Wednesday 16 November and will continue overnight. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Thursday 17 November.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. 
Please avoid walking or driving through floodwater and stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  

This message will be updated by 10am on 17 November 2022, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message:
Flooding is possible overnight tonight from 6pm Wednesday 16 November and into Thursday morning. 

Heavy rain is forecast this afternoon and evening, especially over high ground where large totals are possible. 

This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from late afternoon Wednesday 16 November and into Thursday morning. We expect river levels to remain high throughout this period, though no flooding to properties is currently expected. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated if the situation changes.

River levels are remaining high on the Middle Dorset Stour.
Areas most at risk include tributaries between Sturminster Newton and Wimborne.
Flooding is possible at tributaries between Sturminster Newton and Wimborne from 09:00 AM on 16/11/2022.
Further rainfall is forecast throughout the afternoon.
River levels are high and forecast to rise further.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall yesterday and overnight. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue throughout today, 16/11/2022. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads around Water Lane and Haxted Road. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further rainfall is forecast over the next two days. We expect river levels to remain high until Thursday, 17/11/2022. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers and actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued. This message will be updated this evening, 16/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Littlemead Brook, Cranleigh Waters, Hascombe Stream

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels remain high on the Cranleigh Waters and Littlemead Brook following earlier heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue this morning 16/11/22. Further showers are forecast today with more persistent heavy rain this evening. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated this evening, 16/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Darent from Westerham to Dartford
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels have risen as a result of heavy and persistent rainfall overnight and during the morning of Wednesday. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours, and we expect river levels to rise again overnight and throughout Thursday 17/11/2022. Flooding of roads and low-lying land is possible today, 16/11/2022 and through until Thursday and Friday. Property flooding is not currently expected, though we are prepared to issue Flood Warnings if required. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing trash screens across the catchment. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10:00 on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

The Western Rother is particularly high between Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth. Over the last 36 hours, 45mm of rain (half a month's rainfall) has been recorded at Liss. Flood water will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and approach properties at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth. A further 20-30mm of rain is expected from 15:00 Wednesday afternoon (16/11/22) into the early hours of Thursday morning. The Western Rother will rise again in all locations, bringing a risk of flooding. Property flooding is likely at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth from 03:00 17/11/2022, but also possible between Liss and Midhurst. Thursday, Friday and Saturday should be mostly dry. But river levels in Fittleworth will not begin to fall until Thursday evening (17/11/22). Early actions to reduce potential impacts at Lodsbridge and Fittleworth are encouraged. Please plan to avoid driving through roads prone to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 10:00 17/11/22.

The Powdermill Stream and Combe Haven are high and rising. In the last 36 hours 20mm of rain has been recorded at Powdermill. Another 20-30mm of rain is forecast Wednesday afternoon and evening.  From 19:00 16/11/2022 flooding could affect fields, rural roads and a small number of properties in Crowhurst. Potentially including Crowhurst Recreation Ground, riverside properties on Forewood Lane and properties between the Plough public house and the junction of Sampsons Lane on Sandrock Hill. From 02:00 17/11/2022 water may also affect Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Wednesday's rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday 17/11/2022, leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river should begin to fall in Crowhurst by 10:00 17/11/2022, but will be higher than normal until the weekend. River levels could end up higher than the peaks of last week. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Crowhurst as a precaution, if you have them. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 17/11/2022.

The River Arun is high and rising. In the last 36 hours, nearly half a month's rain (36mm) has been recorded at Itchingfield. This is a lot in a short period. From 19:00 16/11/2022 flooding could affect gardens of Tanbridge Park and Blackbridge Court and fields behind Arunside. From 23:00 16/11/2022 flood water will affect fields and gardens of isolated mill properties between Broadbridge Heath and Pallingham Quay, including the A272 Newbridge road near Billingshurst. From 02:00 17/11/2022 properties at Pallingham Lock could be affected. A further 20-30mm of rain is expected Wednesday evening. Thursday and Friday are forecast to be dry. The river should begin to fall by 14:00 17/11/2022 in Horsham and Friday at Pallingham Quay. The River Arun will be higher than normal until the weekend. River levels could end up higher than last week. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Wanford, if you have them. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 12:00 17/11/2022.

The River Lox is high and rising. Over the last day 20mm of rain has been recorded at Chiddingfold. Flooding could affect fields, rural roads, gardens along the length of the river Lox and approach properties near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood and isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold. Flood water may also affect riverside properties on Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. A further 20-30mm of rain is expected from Wednesday afternoon into the early hours of Thursday morning. The river level should begin to fall by Thursday morning as no further significant rain is forecast. Please operate private water control structures to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 10:00 17/11/22.

The Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes are high and rising. Over the last day, 30mm of rain has been recorded at Westergate. Flooding could affect a small number of riverside properties in Marshall Close, and along Lake Lane. Barnham Road near the Trading Post and the road junction of Barnham Lane and Lake Lane could be affected by flood water. Flooding will affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, as well as possibly parts of the car park at Tesco and land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. A further 20-30mm of rain is expected from Wednesday afternoon into the early hours of Thursday morning. The river levels should begin to fall by Thursday morning as no further significant rain is forecast. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed if you have them. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are clearing grilles through Barnham, including at the Trading Post and our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 10:00 17/11/22.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible during the afternoon of Wednesday 16th November into Thursday Morning. 
 
Following heavy rainfall over the last 24 hours catchments in this area remain wet and sensitive to any further rainfall.
 
During Wednesday afternoon, a further low-pressure system will affect this area, bringing heavy rain and strong winds.  Up to 35mm of rainfall is forecast for some locations. 
 
River levels are forecast to rise in response. The highest levels are forecast during Wednesday night into Thursday morning.  The main areas of concern are low lying land and roads close to the river.
 
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We will continue to monitor river levels and issue Flood Warnings if required.  Trash screens and blockages have been cleared in this area. This message will be updated on Thursday morning (17/11/22) or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Exe, River Batherm, River Lowman, River Haddeo

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Coly, River Yarty, Umborne Brook

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teign, River Bovey, River Lemon, River Kenn

items.message:

During Wednesday afternoon, a further low-pressure system will affect this area, bringing heavy rain and strong winds.  Up to 35mm of rainfall forecast for some locations.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We will continue to monitor river levels and issue Flood Warnings if required.  Trash screens and blockages have been cleared in this area. This message will be updated on Thursday morning (17/11/22) or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels are expected to rise at the Chiselborough, Ashford Mill and Donyatt river gauges due to heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 16/11/22. Areas most at risk are roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges. The lower River Parrett is forecast to be bankfull and overtopping could occur. Further heavy showers are expected over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation and our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Thursday, 17/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Plym, Tory Brook, Long Brook

items.message:
Flooding is possible from late this afternoon Wednesday 16 November and into the early hours of Thursday morning. 

Persistent rain is forecast this afternoon and evening Wednesday 16 November, followed by heavy showers overnight. Some of this rain could be heavy, especially over high ground. 

This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the rivers from late this afternoon and into the early hours of Thursday morning.  

We expect river levels to remain high throughout this period, though no flooding to properties is currently expected. Further heavy showers are forecast over the next few days.  

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by 10am Thursday morning, or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels will rise on the Upper Dorset Frome, Hooke River due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper Dorset Frome, Hooke River, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Toller Whelme and Dorchester.
Flooding is possible at tributaries between Toller Whelme and Dorchester from 05:00 PM on 16/11/2022.
Further rainfall is forecast this evening.
River levels will rise at the Hooke, Maiden Newton gauge.
People in the areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

The Flood Warning has now been removed as river levels on the Upper Dorset Frome are slowly dropping. Be aware that standing water and debris may still remain. There are showers forecast for this evening (15/11/22) and tomorrow morning (16/11/22) but these are not expected to increase river levels We will continue to monitor the forecast and issue an alert if necessary.

items.description: River Parrett (upper) from South Perrott to Thorney
items.message: This Flood Warning has been removed. River levels are falling but can rise very quickly in response to heavy rainfall.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.  Further showery rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Rivers in the Forest of Dean
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Stour, River Lodden, River Shreen

items.message: River levels are rising steadily on the Upper Dorset Stour, Shreen Water. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Upper Dorset Stour, Shreen Water, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Gillingham and Sturminster Newton. Flooding is possible at tributaries between Gillingham and Sturminster Newton from 06:00 PM on 15/11/2022. Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon. River levels are forecast to rise further at the Colesbrook, Gillingham Le Neubourg Way, Hammoon, Lodden Bridge, Milton on Stour gauge. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 12 noon on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels are stable at the Brokenborough, Fosseway and Great Somerford but will rise again on Wednesday evening in response to the forecast rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect the road at Reybridge with river levels peaking between 7am and 10am on Thursday 17th Novemner.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff have been clearing weed screens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated on the morning of Thursday 17th November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Middle Stour from Hammoon to Sturminster Marshall
items.message: River levels continue to rise on the Middle Dorset Stour due to the rainfall in the last 36hours. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Dorset Stour, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Hammoon, Bere Marsh, Stourpaine, Durweston and Lower Blandford St Mary. Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon which may lead to further river rises. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. Consider activating any property flood protection products. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Plan driving routes to avoid the Hammoon road as the gates are locked closed as the road has been affected by flooding. This message will be updated 11:00 AM on the 17/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Stour and Iwerne at Stourpaine
items.message: River levels continue to rise on the Middle Dorset Stour due to the rainfall in the last 36hours. Areas most at risk include Havelins and the SPFA sports pavilion areas in Stourpaine. Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon which may lead to further river rises. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Consider activating any property flood protection products. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Consider putting your flood plan into action. This message will be updated by 12:00 Noon on 17/11/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 6.99 m and is rising by approximately 4 mm per hour. Wet weather is forecast for Wednesday evening, 16/11/2022 and into the early hours of Thursday. The River Yeo at Muchelney is stable. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Thursday 17/11/2022 or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Great Stour, East Stour, Aylesford Stream, Ruckinge Dyke, Whitewater Dyke, Stour

items.message:
River levels are rising as a result of heavy rainfall overnight and this morning.  Flooding of low lying land is expected from 12pm today, 16/11/22. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads along Aylesford Stream, River Great Stour and the River East Stour, particularly in and around Ashford. Further widespread heavy rainfall is forecast this evening and into tomorrow morning on 17/11/22.  River levels are expected to rise again overnight in response to this further heavy rainfall. 

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking our defences and structures.  Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued.  

This message will be updated by 10pm this evening, Wednesday 16 November or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising on the Lower Dorset Frome due to heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lower Dorset Frome, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham.
No property flooding is expected.
Flooding is possible at tributaries between Dorchester and Wareham from 12:00 PM on 16/11/2022.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast this evening.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 12:00 PM on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Avon, River Erme, River Harbourne

items.message:
Flooding is possible during the afternoon of Wednesday 16th November into Thursday Morning. 
 
Following heavy rainfall over the last 24 hours catchments in this area remain wet and sensitive to any further rainfall.

During Wednesday afternoon, a further low-pressure system will affect this area, bringing heavy rain and strong winds.  Up to 35mm of rainfall forecast for some locations. 
 
River levels are forecast to rise in response. The highest levels are forecast during Wednesday night into Thursday morning.  The main areas of concern are low lying land and roads close to the river.

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. We will continue to monitor river levels and issue Flood Warnings if required.  Trash screens and blockages have been cleared in this area. This message will be updated on Thursday morning (17/11/22) or earlier if the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

items.description: North Sea coast from Whitby to Filey

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: This flood alert has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely on Thursday 17/11/2022 between 12:00pm and throughout the afternoon and evening. Areas most at risk include Marine Royal Albert Drive and Sandside in Scarborough, and exposed coastal roads and promenades where the combination of wave action and spray is expected to cause hazardous conditions. Please be careful along beaches and exposed coastal areas as waves and spray may be unpredictable. We continue to monitor the forecast closely. This message will be updated by 11:00am on 17/11/2022, or earlier as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible this evening Wednesday 16 November and into the early hours of Thursday morning. 

Persistent rain is forecast this afternoon and evening Wednesday 16 November, followed by heavy showers overnight. Some of this rain could be heavy, especially over high ground. 

This may result in flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from around 5pm this evening and into the early hours of Thursday morning.  

We expect river levels to remain high throughout this period, though no flooding to properties is currently expected. Further heavy showers are forecast over the next few days.  

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.  We are monitoring river levels and have staff in the area checking for and clearing blockages. This message will be updated by 10am Thursday morning, or earlier if the situation changes.

The Western Rother is high and rising. In the last 36 hours, nearly half a month's rain (47mm) has been recorded at Iping. From 18:00 Wednesday (16/11/2022) flooding will be extensive in fields. Flood water will affect Fittleworth Mill, and nearby properties in Fittleworth. The B2138 Lower Street road over the river at Fittleworth could be impassable. The river rise should slow down this evening, however a further 20-30mm of rain is expected between 15:00 Wednesday and 04:00 Thursday (17/11/2022). The Western Rother will rise again Thursday morning. Thursday and Friday are forecast to be dry. The river might not begin to fall until the early hours of Friday, and will be higher than normal until next week. River levels could end up higher than the peaks of last week. Some roads, including the B2138 through Fittleworth, may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 17/11/2022.

River levels are rising on the River Nadder due to heavy rainfall.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast this evening which will cause river levels to rise again.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Nadder, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the River Nadder and tributaries between Donhead St Mary and Salisbury.
Flooding is possible at the River Nadder and tributaries between Donhead St Mary and Salisbury from 06:00 PM on 16/11/2022.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast this evening.
River levels are rising at the Tisbury gauge.
We are clearing debris from weed screens in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

The River Adur is high, following 36mm of rain in the last 36 hours. Another 20-30mm of rain is forecast Wednesday afternoon and evening. From 23:00 on Wednesday (16/11/2022) minor flooding could affect locations near Slaughter Bridge on Coolham Road, as well as isolated farm buildings, fields and rural roads between Coolham and Henfield. It is possible water may approach gardens of Church Close, Shipley. The rain is expected to clear by 04:00 Thursday (17/11/2022), leaving Thursday and Friday mostly dry. The river should begin to fall by 14:00 on 17/11/2022, but will be higher than normal until Friday. River levels could end up higher than peaks of the last week. Some roads, including Coolham Road at Slaughter Bridge, may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 13:00 17/11/2022.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, North Somerset, Somerset
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Chew, Chew Stoke Stream, Winford Brook

items.message:
River levels will rise on the River Chew, Winford Brook, Chew Stoke Stream due to heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include the fords on Mill Lane and Pilgrims Way in Chew Stoke and The Batch and Dumpers Lane in Chew Magna..
Flooding is possible at these locations from 09:00 PM on 16/11/2022.
Rainfall is forecast overnight which will cause river levels to rise.
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated on Wednesday morning, 17th November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Medway between Forest Row and Penshurst
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise as a result of heavy rainfall. Flooding of property, roads and low-lying land is expected between 9pm this evening, Wednesday 16 November, and 9am tomorrow, Thursday 17 November 2022. We expect flooding to affect properties on and around Beech Green Lane and Rogues Hill, near the river Medway at Hartfield.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 6 hours until 11pm on 16 November. We expect river levels to remain high overnight.

We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from the River Medway.
Please avoid walking or driving through floodwater and remain aware in case the situation changes. 

This message will be updated by 10am on Thursday 17 November or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mersey Uplands catchment including Hyde, Ashton-under-Lyne, Denton, Stalybridge and Glossop

floodArea.county: Barnsley, Cheshire East, Derbyshire, Oldham, Stockport, Tameside

items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Mersey due to heavy rainfall on Thursday 17/11/2022.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Mersey, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying land and roads around the Rivers Goyt, Tame, Sett and Etherow and their tributaries from 07:00 AM on 17/11/2022.
Rainfall is expected throughout the day tomorrow (17/1//2022) resulting in rising river levels.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 04:00 PM on 17/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brue, River Sheppey, North Drain, South Drain

items.message: Levels are forecast to rise at Bruton Dam as a result of this evenings rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads, farmland and property is possible Wednesday evening,16/11/22 and into the early hours of Thursday.  Areas most at risk are the B3151 Glastonbury to Meare Road.  Overtopping is possible from the Glastonbury Millstream and the River Brue at North Drain and Westhay.  The River Brue is forecast to be bankfull upstream of Bruton Dam with field flooding likely. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences and clearing weed screens. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Thursday, 17/11/22, or as the situation changes.
